articles.headline: Trump’s Surprising New Ally in Mexico? The Government
articles.snippet: Mexican officials say this prevents a fight with Trump and costs little, politically, at home. But it defies López Obrador’s promises to defend migrants.
articles.abstract: Mexican officials say this prevents a fight with Trump and costs little, politically, at home. But it defies López Obrador’s promises to defend migrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexican officials are carrying out the Trump administration’s immigration agenda across wide stretches of the border, undercutting the Mexican government’s promises to defend migrants and support their search for a better life.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Kirk Semple

articles.headline: Lyft’s I.P.O. Filing Reveals Nearly $1 Billion in Losses
articles.snippet: The ride-sharing company unveiled the prospectus for its initial public offering. It leads a wave of well-known tech start-ups that plan to go public this year.
articles.abstract: The ride-sharing company unveiled the prospectus for its initial public offering. It leads a wave of well-known tech start-ups that plan to go public this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Lyft pulled back the curtain on its business for the first time on Friday as it prepared to go public, officially starting the countdown on a horde of technology offerings that are set to bring new wealth to Silicon Valley this year.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: When Women Control the Money, Female Founders Get Funded
articles.snippet: At a pitch night in SoHo, female entrepreneurs pitch female venture capitalists.
articles.abstract: At a pitch night in SoHo, female entrepreneurs pitch female venture capitalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: Female entrepreneurs have long known how hard it is to raise money from a roomful of men. “I would walk into these rooms of late-40s, early-50s dudes — potential investors — and they would just look at me blankly, like, ‘I do not get it,’” said Rachel Drori, the founder of Daily Harvest, a delivery service for produce-centric meals. “Sometimes, they’d say, ‘Can you send samples to my wife?’”

articles.headline: The Fall of ‘America’s Money Answers Man’
articles.snippet: From Time Inc. to a Ponzi scheme: The journey of Jordan Goodman.
articles.abstract: From Time Inc. to a Ponzi scheme: The journey of Jordan Goodman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Spin your radio dial, download a podcast or sit down at your next corporate gathering and you’ll have no trouble finding a self-styled financial guru to tell you what to do with your money.

articles.headline: At an HBO Premiere Party, the C.E.O.’s Seat Was Empty
articles.snippet: The guests discuss Richard Plepler’s influence on the network behind “Game of Thrones” — and ponder what lies ahead as AT&T asserts control.
articles.abstract: The guests discuss Richard Plepler’s influence on the network behind “Game of Thrones” — and ponder what lies ahead as AT&T asserts control.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be another one of those glittery New York nights for Richard Plepler, with a screening of a new HBO documentary followed by a dinner party at Porter House, a spacious steak restaurant with a view of Central Park. But Mr. Plepler, the HBO chief executive, who announced his resignation on Thursday, was not among the roughly 200 filmmakers, screenwriters, journalists and HBO employees who filed in around 9:30.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Edmund Lee

articles.headline: Online and Making Thousands, at Age 4: Meet the Kidfluencers
articles.snippet: Brands are giving lucrative endorsement deals to young children on YouTube and Instagram, raising questions about whether their young followers should be seeing that kind of marketing.
articles.abstract: Brands are giving lucrative endorsement deals to young children on YouTube and Instagram, raising questions about whether their young followers should be seeing that kind of marketing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samia was an influencer before she could talk.

articles.headline: Trudeau Promised a Fresh Approach to Politics. Now He’s Embroiled in Scandal.
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has been drawn into scandal around a corporation accused of corruption and his former justice minister, who said his office pressured her to drop the case.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has been drawn into scandal around a corporation accused of corruption and his former justice minister, who said his office pressured her to drop the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada promised a fresh approach to politics, one that was based on openness, decency and liberalism.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Trump Faces Fury After Saying He Believes North Korean Leader on Student’s Death
articles.snippet: The family of Otto Warmbier spoke out after President Trump’s comments, saying that North Korea’s “evil regime” was responsible for the death of their son.
articles.abstract: The family of Otto Warmbier spoke out after President Trump’s comments, saying that North Korea’s “evil regime” was responsible for the death of their son.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the American college student Otto Warmbier was released from a North Korea prison in 2017, unresponsive and not expected to survive, his father, Fred, spoke of a comforting phone call from President Trump: “It was gracious, it was nice and it felt good.”
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Kevin Williams

articles.headline: Behind Illicit Massage Parlors Lie a Vast Crime Network and Modern Indentured Servitude
articles.snippet: In a $3 billion-a-year industry, many women stay on as prostitutes in order to pay debts to smugglers, spa owners and lawyers.
articles.abstract: In a $3 billion-a-year industry, many women stay on as prostitutes in order to pay debts to smugglers, spa owners and lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: She was 49, a recent immigrant and deeply in debt to a loan shark back home in China when she answered an employment ad three years ago that promised thousands of dollars a month, but offered no job description. She realized too late that she had been tricked into working at a massage parlor in Flushing, Queens, where besides kneading backs, she was expected to sexually service up to a dozen men a day.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Frances Robles and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: How Jeff Bezos Went to Hollywood and Lost Control
articles.snippet: He built the world’s largest fortune with an iron discipline. Now a wild cast of only-in-L.A. characters have seized his narrative.
articles.abstract: He built the world’s largest fortune with an iron discipline. Now a wild cast of only-in-L.A. characters have seized his narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos amassed the world’s greatest fortune by relying on what he has called a “regret minimization framework.” He built an $800 billion company with 14 codified principles and a brutally exacting culture. His annual salary of $81,840 has not budged since 1998.

articles.headline: Can Israel Survive Without Netanyahu? Israelis Imagine the Future
articles.snippet: Benjamin Netanyahu’s main argument for re-election is that Israel needs him. But with his campaign facing serious challenges, Israelis are asking if that’s true.
articles.abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu’s main argument for re-election is that Israel needs him. But with his campaign facing serious challenges, Israelis are asking if that’s true.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The pre-Sabbath rush was on at Reuven and Negina Abramove’s grocery store in Rehovot, a city that’s been called Israel’s Ohio for its tendency to mirror the results of national elections. But the proprietors were stuck on the unthinkable: Israel without Benjamin Netanyahu as prime minister.

articles.headline: How the Trump-Kim Summit Failed: Big Threats, Big Egos, Bad Bets
articles.snippet: President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea had dramatically different visions of what “denuclearization” meant, dooming their deal.
articles.abstract: President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea had dramatically different visions of what “denuclearization” meant, dooming their deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — As President Trump settled into the dining room of a French-colonial hotel in Hanoi on Thursday morning, the conversation with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader with whom he had struck up the oddest of friendships, was already turning tense.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Michael Jackson Documentary Revives Lurid Claims, Imperiling His Thriving Estate
articles.snippet: Mr. Jackson died deep in debt. Now his estate is worth billions. Will the new film, “Leaving Neverland,” focused on two men’s accounts of sexual abuse, damage his posthumous career?
articles.abstract: Mr. Jackson died deep in debt. Now his estate is worth billions. Will the new film, “Leaving Neverland,” focused on two men’s accounts of sexual abuse, damage his posthumous career?
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Jackson’s damaged reputation began to recover the day he died.

articles.headline: ‘You Have to Pay With Your Body’: The Hidden Nightmare of Sexual Violence on the Border
articles.snippet: Of all the hazards facing migrant women along the southwest border, one of the most ubiquitous and devastating is sexual assault.
articles.abstract: Of all the hazards facing migrant women along the southwest border, one of the most ubiquitous and devastating is sexual assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: MCALLEN, Tex. — It was dark in the stash house where they kept her, the windows covered so no one could see inside. At first, the smugglers had her cook for the other migrants who had recently crossed illegally into the United States. Then they took her to a room upstairs, locked the door and began taking turns with her.

articles.headline: To Woo a Skeptical Trump, Intelligence Chiefs Talk Economics Instead of Spies
articles.snippet: While the professionals do not criticize Mr. Trump’s focus, they question whether those interests are crowding out intelligence on threats like terrorism.
articles.abstract: While the professionals do not criticize Mr. Trump’s focus, they question whether those interests are crowding out intelligence on threats like terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officials who brief the president have warned him about Chinese espionage in bottom-line business terms. They have used Black Sea shipping figures to demonstrate the effect of Russia’s aggression in Ukraine. And they have filled the daily threat briefing with charts and graphs of economic data.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: As Uber Prepares to Go Public, This Man Is Racing to Clean It Up
articles.snippet: Tony West, Uber’s chief legal officer and a former Justice Department official, is navigating the ride-hailing giant’s numerous legal issues.
articles.abstract: Tony West, Uber’s chief legal officer and a former Justice Department official, is navigating the ride-hailing giant’s numerous legal issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Not long after Tony West joined Uber as chief legal officer in November 2017, he began a delicate task: crafting a transparency report to quantify how many people had been sexually assaulted during Uber rides.

articles.headline: After India Loses Dogfight to Pakistan, Questions Arise About Its ‘Vintage’ Military
articles.snippet: As America strengthens its alliance with India to help counter China, critics say its military faces serious challenges, from the age of its hardware to the size of its budget.
articles.abstract: As America strengthens its alliance with India to help counter China, critics say its military faces serious challenges, from the age of its hardware to the size of its budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It was an inauspicious moment for a military the United States is banking on to help keep an expanding China in check.

articles.headline: As Trump and Kim Met, North Korean Hackers Hit Over 100 Targets in U.S. and Ally Nations
articles.snippet: McAfee researchers watched, in real time, as the North Koreans attacked the networks of companies in the United States and around the globe.
articles.abstract: McAfee researchers watched, in real time, as the North Koreans attacked the networks of companies in the United States and around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — North Korean hackers who have targeted American and European businesses for 18 months kept up their attacks last week even as President Trump was meeting with North Korea’s leader in Hanoi.

articles.headline: Amazon’s Hard Bargain Extends Far Beyond New York
articles.snippet: Amazon often plays politics with a distinctive message: Give us what we want, or we’ll leave and take our jobs elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Amazon often plays politics with a distinctive message: Give us what we want, or we’ll leave and take our jobs elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Texas officials pushed Amazon to pay nearly $270 million in back sales taxes in 2010, Amazon responded by closing its only warehouse in the state and scrapping expansion plans there. Two years later, the officials agreed to waive the past taxes in exchange for Amazon opening new warehouses.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise, Manny Fernandez and John Eligon

articles.headline: U.S. and China Near a Trade Deal to Drop Tariffs
articles.snippet: The Trump administration’s agreement is shaping up to be less ambitious than what the president and his top advisers initially set out to win.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration’s agreement is shaping up to be less ambitious than what the president and his top advisers initially set out to win.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is close to a trade deal with China that would roll back tariffs on both sides of the Pacific but may do little to achieve the substantive changes to China’s economy that the United States initially set out to win, people with knowledge of the talks said.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: With Big Stars and Paid Subscriptions, Luminary Aims to Be the Netflix of Podcasts
articles.snippet: Luminary is unveiling nearly $100 million in funding and a subscription-based business model that it hopes will push podcasting into a new phase of growth.
articles.abstract: Luminary is unveiling nearly $100 million in funding and a subscription-based business model that it hopes will push podcasting into a new phase of growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Patti LuPone as a bebop-singing junkie nun in John Cameron Mitchell’s musical follow-up to “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.” A new show from Lena Dunham called “The C-Word.” Series from Conan O’Brien, Malcolm Gladwell and Trevor Noah.

articles.headline: Nursing Homes Are Closing Across Rural America, Scattering Residents
articles.snippet: As financial pressures have forced scores of small-town nursing homes to shut down, their residents often must relocate far from their families to find care.
articles.abstract: As financial pressures have forced scores of small-town nursing homes to shut down, their residents often must relocate far from their families to find care.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOBRIDGE, S.D. — Harold Labrensz spent much of his 89-year life farming and ranching the rolling Dakota plains along the Missouri River. His family figured he would die there, too.

articles.headline: Why Napalm Is a Cautionary Tale for Tech Giants Pursuing Military Contracts
articles.snippet: Dow Chemical stopped making napalm for the military in 1969, just four years after it began. But the reputational damage haunted the company for decades.
articles.abstract: Dow Chemical stopped making napalm for the military in 1969, just four years after it began. But the reputational damage haunted the company for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past few months, a fierce debate has erupted in Silicon Valley over whether large technology companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft should join forces with the United States military, along with agencies like Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

articles.headline: A New Luxury Retreat Caters to Elderly Workers in Tech (Ages 30 and Up)
articles.snippet: At Modern Elder Academy, on the Baja coast, guests share anxieties about ageism and obsolescence.
articles.abstract: At Modern Elder Academy, on the Baja coast, guests share anxieties about ageism and obsolescence.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PESCADERO, Mexico — At a luxury resort in Baja California Sur, everyone was recovering from a long day sharing how hard it felt to be getting older.

articles.headline: AT&T Assembles a Media Team, Joining a Battle With Giants
articles.snippet: The company’s two core businesses are both facing upheaval as tech companies like Amazon, Netflix, Apple, Google and Facebook have become dominant players in both entertainment and distribution.
articles.abstract: The company’s two core businesses are both facing upheaval as tech companies like Amazon, Netflix, Apple, Google and Facebook have become dominant players in both entertainment and distribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new AT&T is coming into focus.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and John Koblin

articles.headline: Google Finds It’s Underpaying Many Men as It Addresses Wage Equity
articles.snippet: After a recent study, the company gave raises to thousands of men after determining they were earning less than women in similar jobs.
articles.abstract: After a recent study, the company gave raises to thousands of men after determining they were earning less than women in similar jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Google conducted a study recently to determine whether the company was underpaying women and members of minority groups, it found, to the surprise of just about everyone, that men were paid less money than women for doing similar work.
